articles.title: From rural margins to media trailblazers: India’s women journalists are rewriting the news
articles.summary: Far from global newsrooms and editorial boardrooms, a radically different model of journalism has been taking shape for over two decades in rural India.
articles.content:
Khabar Lahariya, literally “news waves”, is an all-women media organisation run since 2002 by rural reporters, many of them Dalit, Adivasi and Muslim, dispatching fresh stories from some of the most marginalised regions.

“We faced challenges at every level,” founder Kavita Devi told UN News. “People would say women can’t be journalists, but we went to villages, persisted and proved that women can not only report but tell stories that others cannot.”

Long before global conversations about diversity entered newsrooms, these women were building their own.

From illiterate to multimedia producer

Villagers initially doubted women could be journalists and educational barriers made recruiting reporters a daunting challenge, Ms. Devi said, recalling the scepticism they encountered.

At the time, female reporters were virtually absent from newsrooms in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar. Many of the women who joined Khabar Lahariya had little formal education.

One such journalist, Shyamkali, transformed from being illiterate to becoming a senior reporter.

© Khabhar Lahariya Khabar Lahariya reports in local languages, including Bundeli, Awadhi and Bhojpuri, rejecting the idea that legitimacy requires elite, urban Hindi or English.

Reporting from the margins

“I didn’t know how to write a resume or handle a camera, but with training and guidance, I was able to learn everything, from interviewing to mobile journalism, and now I report stories that mainstream media ignore,” Shyamkali told UN News.

Khabar Lahariya’s reporting also goes beyond mere representation. Shyamkali recounted a story about a woman who, driven to desperation, acted violently against her abusive husband.

Mainstream media reported the incident without context, focusing only on the shocking act, she said. But, Shyamkali’s reporting brought the woman’s perspective and underlying social realities to light, demonstrating how women journalists can add nuance, empathy and depth to stories often ignored or misrepresented.

Women ‘see their own image in the news’

Language plays a critical role in Khabar Lahariya’s mission. Publishing in local dialects like Bundeli, Awadhi and Bhojpuri, ensures that news is accessible, relatable and empowering for rural communities.

“When we explain issues in their language, people understand better,” Ms. Devi said.

“They see their own image in the news, especially women.”

Game changing digital media

Transitioning from print to digital platforms has been a game changer for Khabar Lahariya, with its staff embracing mobile journalism, learning to anchor, produce and share news on social media platforms like Facebook, YouTube and Instagram.

Technology has empowered us to amplify voices from communities that were always ignored.

“Technology has empowered us to amplify voices from communities that were always ignored,” Shyamkali said, recalling the initial fear and excitement of tackling digital media.

“I never imagined handling a camera or sending live reports from a phone, but now I can.”

This digital expansion not only increases visibility, but enhances women’s agency, confidence and economic independence, proving that technology and training can transform social realities at the grassroots level.

© Khabhar Lahariya Founded in 2002, Khabar Lahariya is an all-women media organisation run by rural reporters, many of them Dalit, Adivasi and Muslim.

Telling the whole story

Women remain just one in four people seen, heard or read about in the media, according to the 2025 Global Media Monitoring Project (GMMP) report.

When women’s voices are missing, the public is denied half the story.

Kalliopi Mingeirou, chief of UN Women’s section to end violence against women and girls, told UN News “this is not because women lack expertise or leadership” but because media continues to rely on the same narrow set of voices, too often defaulting to men as experts and decision makers.

Indeed, democracy depends on informed debate and inclusive decision making, she said.

“When women’s voices are missing, the public is denied half the story,” she said. “This distorts reality, weakens accountability and narrows the democratic space. In today’s context of backlash against gender equality, the exclusion of women in news is not only a gender issue, it is a democratic deficit.”

‘Radical rethink’ required

Progress on gender representation in media has not only stalled, it is under threat, according to the new report.

“These findings are both a wake-up call and a call to action,” said Kirsi Madi, Deputy Executive Director of UN Women. “When women are missing, democracy is incomplete.”

Despite making up half of the world’s population, women today account for just 26 per cent of news subjects and sources globally, a figure that has barely shifted in the last 15 years, the report found.

“A radical rethink is needed so that media can play its role in advancing equality,” Ms. Madi said. “Without women’s voices, there is no full story, no fair democracy, no lasting security and no shared future.”

articles.personality_title: Rural women in India lead a new wave of local journalism
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – For over 20 years, a group of women from rural India, many belonging to marginalized communities like Dalit, Adivasi, and Muslim, have been creating a unique news organization called Khabar Lahariya. These women started with little formal education and faced doubts about their ability to report news.

**What happened** – Since 2002, Khabar Lahariya has been run entirely by these rural women journalists. They report news in local languages such as Bundeli, Awadhi, and Bhojpuri, focusing on stories that mainstream media often ignore or misrepresent. With training, they learned skills from writing to using digital tools and social media, helping them share their stories widely.

**Impact** – This work is important because it gives a voice to communities and women who rarely appear in news. For example, one reporter, Shyamkali, went from being illiterate to a senior journalist, telling stories with more depth and understanding than usual media coverage. Publishing in local languages makes the news more relatable and helps people see themselves in the stories.

**What's next step** – Khabar Lahariya is expanding its digital presence, using mobile journalism and social media to reach more people. This growth not only increases visibility but also strengthens women’s independence and confidence. The success of this model encourages other marginalized groups to use media for their own stories.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Rural women journalists in India are transforming local news by sharing unheard stories in their own languages, using technology to empower their communities and promote gender equality.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des femmes rurales en Inde, pionnières d’un nouveau journalisme local
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Depuis plus de 20 ans, un groupe de femmes issues des zones rurales en Inde, souvent Dalit, Adivasi ou musulmanes, a créé une organisation d’information unique appelée Khabar Lahariya. Ces femmes, peu ou pas scolarisées, ont dû faire face à des doutes sur leur capacité à faire du journalisme.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Depuis 2002, Khabar Lahariya est entièrement dirigé par ces journalistes rurales. Elles rapportent des nouvelles dans des langues locales comme le Bundeli, l’Awadhi et le Bhojpuri, en se concentrant sur des histoires souvent ignorées ou mal représentées par les médias classiques. Grâce à des formations, elles ont appris à écrire et à utiliser les outils numériques et les réseaux sociaux pour diffuser leurs récits.

**Impact** – Ce travail est important car il donne une voix aux communautés et aux femmes rarement visibles dans les médias. Par exemple, Shyamkali, une journaliste qui était illettrée, est devenue reporter principale, racontant des histoires avec plus de profondeur et de compréhension que les médias habituels. Publier dans des langues locales rend l’information plus accessible et aide les gens à se reconnaître dans les récits.

**Prochaine étape** – Khabar Lahariya développe sa présence numérique en utilisant le journalisme mobile et les réseaux sociaux pour toucher un plus large public. Cette expansion augmente la visibilité et renforce aussi l’indépendance et la confiance des femmes. Ce succès encourage d’autres groupes marginalisés à utiliser les médias pour raconter leurs propres histoires.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Des femmes journalistes rurales en Inde transforment l’information locale en partageant des histoires ignorées dans leurs langues, utilisant la technologie pour renforcer leurs communautés et promouvoir l’égalité des sexes.
articles.personality_title_es: Mujeres rurales en India lideran una nueva ola de periodismo local
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante más de 20 años, un grupo de mujeres de zonas rurales en India, muchas de comunidades marginadas como Dalit, Adivasi y musulmanas, han creado una organización de noticias llamada Khabar Lahariya. Estas mujeres comenzaron con poca educación formal y enfrentaron dudas sobre su capacidad para reportar noticias.

**Qué pasó** – Desde 2002, Khabar Lahariya ha sido dirigida completamente por estas periodistas rurales. Informan en idiomas locales como Bundeli, Awadhi y Bhojpuri, enfocándose en historias que los medios principales suelen ignorar o representar mal. Con capacitación, aprendieron desde redacción hasta uso de herramientas digitales y redes sociales para compartir sus noticias.

**Impacto** – Este trabajo es importante porque da voz a comunidades y mujeres que rara vez aparecen en las noticias. Por ejemplo, una reportera llamada Shyamkali pasó de ser analfabeta a periodista principal, contando historias con mayor profundidad y comprensión que los medios comunes. Publicar en lenguas locales hace que las noticias sean más accesibles y ayuda a las personas a verse reflejadas en las historias.

**Próximo paso** – Khabar Lahariya está expandiendo su presencia digital, usando periodismo móvil y redes sociales para llegar a más personas. Este crecimiento aumenta la visibilidad y fortalece la independencia y confianza de las mujeres. El éxito de este modelo anima a otros grupos marginados a usar los medios para contar sus propias historias.

**Resumen en una frase** – Las periodistas rurales en India están transformando las noticias locales al compartir historias no escuchadas en sus propios idiomas, usando tecnología para empoderar a sus comunidades y promover la igualdad de género.
